questions.text: A patient from a military background presented with rash, fever, and altered sensorium. There is also a deficiency of the membrane attacking complex. The likely cause can be: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neisseria meningitidis

 

Neisseria meningitidis is a bacterium that commonly causes meningococcal infections, which can lead to serious conditions such as meningococcemia and meningitis. Patients with a deficiency in the membrane attack complex (MAC) of the complement system, specifically components C5 to C9, are at an increased risk of Neisserial infections. The MAC plays a crucial role in defending against Neisseria species by forming pores in the bacterial cell membrane, leading to cell lysis. Without this complex, individuals are susceptible to recurrent or disseminated Neisserial infections, which manifest with symptoms like rash, fever, and altered sensorium, as seen in this patient. The clinical presentation of rash, fever, and altered sensorium strongly suggests meningococcemia, a severe form of infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): CMV is a type of herpesvirus that can cause a variety of symptoms, primarily in immunocompromised individuals, but it does not typically present with rash, fever, and altered sensorium linked to MAC deficiency.

 

Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae: This bacterium is associated with pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and other infections, particularly in hospital settings. It does not have a direct correlation with MAC deficiency and does not typically present with disseminated infections characterized by rash, fever, and altered sensorium.

 

Option D. Hemophilus influenzae: While Hemophilus influenzae can cause respiratory tract infections and meningitis, it is not specifically associated with MAC deficiency and does not fit the profile of disseminated Neisserial infections seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with deficiencies in the membrane attack complex (C5-C9) of the complement system are particularly susceptible to infections caused by Neisseria species, such as Neisseria meningitidis, which can lead to severe conditions like meningococcemia.

questions.text: Which is the most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) B + C (Posterolateral variety and Bochdalek hernia)

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the Bochdalek hernia, which occurs in the posterolateral part of the diaphragm. This type of hernia typically presents with abdominal organs, such as the intestines, herniating into the chest cavity, leading to respiratory distress in newborns due to lung compression. Bochdalek hernias account for about 85-90% of all congenital diaphragmatic hernias, making them the most common type.

 

Other Option:

 

Option A. Anteromedial variety: This is a less common form of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and typically occurs in the anterior or medial portion of the diaphragm, which is not the usual presentation associated with congenital cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of congenital diaphragmatic hernia is the Bochdalek hernia, which is located in the posterolateral part of the diaphragm.

choices.text: Typically presents between postoperative days 3 and 5
Suture length should be 4 times the wound length
High incidence if Catgut is used for closure

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Burst Abdomen is not true? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Typically presents between postoperative days 3 and 5

 

Explanation:

 

Burst abdomen (abdominal wound dehiscence) usually occurs after 5-7 days post-laparotomy. This directly contradicts option B, which incorrectly states it typically presents between days 3-5. The condition is characterized by the "salmon fluid sign" where large quantities of serous fluid come out from the wound.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Incidence is 1-3 percent - This represents an accurate statistical range for the occurrence of burst abdomen following laparotomy procedures.

 

Option C. Suture length should be 4 times the wound length - This is a correct technical specification for proper abdominal wall closure to prevent dehiscence, also known as Jenkin’s rule.

 

Option D. High incidence if Catgut is used for closure - This is accurate because catgut is an absorbable suture material associated with higher rates of wound failure compared to more modern synthetic materials.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Burst abdomen is a serious post-operative complication that presents with the salmon fluid sign typically 5-7 days after surgery, requiring emergency management with a Bogota bag laparostomy followed by definitive re-suturing of the abdominal wall.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

 

Laparoscopic Myomectomy:

 

  • Indications for myomectomy in a woman with infertility and fibroid uterus include:
    • Submucous fibroids of any size/location as they interfere with fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
    • Intramural fibroids that:
      • Distort the endometrial cavity.
      • Are larger than 5 cm in size.
  • In this case, the patient has significant intramural fibroids (7x5 cm and 5x3 cm), making laparoscopic myomectomy the appropriate management to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uterine artery embolization: This procedure is not indicated for women who wish to conceive as it can compromise uterine function and future fertility.

 

Option C. Artificial reproductive techniques: While ART could be considered in cases of bilateral tubal block, myomectomy should be done prior to potentially relieve the tubal block, improve ART outcomes, and enhance pregnancy outcomes.

 

Option D. GnRH analogues: GnRH analogues are not suitable for this patient as she is eager to conceive. These are typically used for temporary symptom relief or to shrink fibroids preoperatively, but not as a primary treatment for infertility in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.

 

Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8th edition

questions.text: Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are associated with which vitamin deficiency? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B2

 

Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are clinical manifestations associated with a deficiency in Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin). Riboflavin is essential for various cellular processes, including energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids. Deficiency in riboflavin leads to various symptoms, most notably affecting the mucous membranes, which include angular cheilitis (cracking at the corners of the mouth), stomatitis (inflammation of the mouth and lips), and glossitis (inflammation of the tongue).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Thiamine deficiency is not typically associated with angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis. Instead, it leads to conditions such as Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi, which affect the nervous and cardiovascular systems.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, characterized by the three D's: dermatitis, diarrhea, and dementia. While oral symptoms can occur in severe cases, they usually do not present as angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis.

 

Option D. Vitamin B6: Pyridoxine deficiency is associated with dermatitis, peripheral neuropathy, and certain types of anemia. It is not typically linked with angular cheilitis, stomatitis, or glossitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Angular cheilitis, stomatitis, and glossitis are associated with Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin) deficiency.

questions.text: What are the typical levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH) in a patient with Turner’s syndrome? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High FSH, high LH

 

 In Turner's syndrome, there is gonadal dysgenesis with "streak" gonads that lack follicles and have no potential to produce hormones. This creates a state of hypergonadotropic hypogonadism where the pituitary gland increases its production of gonadotropins (FSH and LH) due to the absence of negative feedback from ovarian hormones, particularly estradiol, which is very low in these patients.

 

Evidence from Source

 

Turner syndrome is characterized by "streak" gonads without any follicles or hormonal potential. Investigations reveal that serum E2 is very low while serum FSH and LH are elevated, confirming the hypergonadotropic hypogonadism state typical of this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. High FSH, low LH: This pattern doesn't occur in Turner's syndrome as both gonadotropins are elevated due to lack of ovarian feedback.

 

Option C. Low FSH, high LH: This hormonal pattern is characteristic of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) where there is preferential LH secretion with normal to low FSH.

 

Option D. Low FSH, low LH: This pattern indicates hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, seen in hypothalamic or pituitary disorders, not Turner's syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner's syndrome represents a classic example of primary gonadal failure (hypergonadotropic hypogonadism) with elevated gonadotropins (FSH and LH) and low estradiol due to dysfunctional streak gonads.

questions.text: Which of the following can grow in an acidic pH? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lactobacilli

 

Among the given options, lactobacilli is the one that can grow in an acidic pH.

 

It is a gram-positive, facultatively anaerobic, non-motile, non-spore-forming bacterium. Lactobacillus derives lactic acid from glucose, creating an acidic environment and thus can grow in an acidic medium. It is found in the vagina as part of its normal microbiota.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrio: Incorrect, as Vibrio species typically prefer alkaline conditions, such as those found in seawater.

 

Option C. Salmonella: Incorrect, Salmonella bacteria prefer a neutral to slightly acidic environment but do not thrive in highly acidic conditions.

 

Option D. Shigella: Incorrect, Shigella, like Salmonella, is more adapted to neutral or slightly acidic environments and does not generally grow well in highly acidic conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactobacilli's ability to grow in acidic environments is crucial for their role in maintaining healthy microbial flora in certain parts of the human body, such as the vagina, and is also exploited in the fermentation of various food products.

questions.text: Which of the following medications may be safely discontinued with minimal risk of adverse effects before an abdominal surgery? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ACE Inhibitors/Angiotensin Receptor Blockers

 

ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) should be omitted on the day of surgery. According to pre-anesthetic evaluation guidelines, while most antihypertensive medications are continued, ACE inhibitors and ARBs are specifically recommended to be withheld due to an increased risk of significant intraoperative hypotension when taken on the morning of surgery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Statins: These should be continued perioperatively to maintain lipid control and vascular protection.

 

Option B. Beta Blockers: These should be continued on the day of surgery. Abrupt discontinuation can lead to rebound hypertension, tachycardia, and an increased risk of myocardial ischemia.

 

Option D. Steroids: Patients on chronic steroid therapy should continue their regular dose and receive supplemental IV hydrocortisone perioperatively. Discontinuing steroids can lead to adrenal insufficiency and hemodynamic instability during surgical stress.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

While most chronic medications are continued perioperatively, ACE inhibitors and ARBs should be withheld on the day of surgery to reduce the risk of intraoperative hypotension. In contrast, beta blockers, statins, and steroids should be continued to avoid potential complications.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best investigation for aneuploidy? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. In Situ Hybridization
  2. Conventional cytogenetics 
  3. PCR
  4. Sanger sequencing
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A & B

 

For the detection of aneuploidy, both In Situ Hybridization (specifically FISH - Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best investigations. "FISH technique is an important technique which not only helps to detect the presence of microdeletions or an excess number of certain types of genes being expressed it also helps to detect the presence of specific chromosomal translocations.

 

Conventional cytogenetics, though more time-consuming than FISH, is still an effective method for aneuploidy detection. It involves visualizing the chromosomes under a microscope during cell division to count them and look for gross abnormalities.

 

Both techniques allow direct visualization of chromosomal material and can detect numerical abnormalities like aneuploidy. FISH is particularly valuable because it can rapidly detect common aneuploidies like trisomy 21, 18, 13 within 24-48 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C & D (PCR and Sanger sequencing): These techniques are not the best for detecting aneuploidy. PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for analyzing specific DNA sequences and mutations, but they cannot effectively detect changes in chromosome number.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FISH (Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization) and conventional cytogenetics are the best techniques for detecting aneuploidy (abnormal chromosome numbers), while PCR and Sanger sequencing are used for specific sequence analysis but not aneuploidy detection.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic ear infection presents with fever, headache, vomiting, irritability, and confusion. His CT brain is shown in the image below. What is the possible diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Temporal lobe abscess

 

The clinical vignette with the given CT image points to a diagnosis of temporal lobe abscess that is most likely to have developed as a complication of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM).

 

Temporal lobe abscess is an intracranial complication of CSOM.

 

Localizing symptoms of temporal lobe abscess -

 

  1. Nominal aphasia. If abscess involves dominant hemisphere, i.e. left hemisphere in right-handed persons, patient fails to tell the names of common objects such as key, pen, etc. but can demonstrate their use.
  2. Homonymous hemianopia. This is due to pressure on the optic radiations. Visual field, opposite to the side of the lesion, is lost. It can be elicited by confrontation test, by standing in front of the patient and comparing his visual field with that of the examiner, or by perimeter. The defect is usually in the upper, but sometimes in the lower quadrants.
  3. Contralateral motor paralysis. In the usual upward spread of abscess, the face is involved first followed by the arm and leg. Inward spread, towards the internal capsule, involves the leg first followed by the arm and the face.
  4. Epileptic fits. Involvement of uncinate gyrus causes hallucinations of taste, and smell and involuntary smacking movements of lips and tongue. Generalized fits may occur.

 

CT brain is the investigation of choice. Brain abscess is seen as a ring-enhancing lesion in imaging studies.

 

Management:

 

  1. IV antibiotics (usually third generation cephalosporin +/- metronidazole) are started. Aminoglycosides are added if pseudomonas infection is suspected. Culture and sensitivity of ear swabs can guide antibiotic therapy.
  2.  Raised intracranial tension can be lowered by dexamethasone, 4 mg i.v. 6 hourly or mannitol 20% in doses of 0.5 g/kg body weight
  3. Surgical: Abscess drainage of the temporal lobe abscess followed by radical mastoidectomy for CSOM is the definitive management in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cerebellar abscess: Would likely present with different symptoms, including severe dizziness, balance problems, and coordination difficulties.

 

Option C. Subdural abscess: Usually presents with more diffuse cerebral symptoms and different radiological features.

 

Option D. Meningitis: Characterized by severe headache, neck stiffness, and photophobia, with different findings on lumbar puncture and imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Temporal lobe abscess is a serious complication of chronic ear infections that requires prompt recognition and aggressive treatment to prevent further neurological damage and potential life-threatening complications.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition pg 90, 91

questions.text: Which of the following anemias is associated with a hypoplastic marrow? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fanconi's Anemia

 

Fanconi's anemia is a constitutional form of aplastic anemia associated with hypoplastic bone marrow. It is an inherited disorder characterized by pancytopenia with bone marrow hypocellularity. Fanconi anemia typically presents in early childhood and is often accompanied by characteristic physical anomalies. The disease is caused by mutations in genes involved in DNA repair, leading to genomic instability and progressive bone marrow failure.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B. Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH): PNH is an acquired clonal stem cell disorder characterized by intravascular hemolysis. While PNH can be associated with bone marrow failure, it typically presents with a cellular bone marrow rather than hypoplasia. PNH is classified under "Pancytopenia with Cellular Bone Marrow."
  • Option C. Hypersplenism: Hypersplenism refers to the premature destruction or sequestration of blood cells by an enlarged spleen. It is a peripheral cause of cytopenia rather than a primary bone marrow disorder. Hypersplenism is classified under pancytopenia with cellular bone marrow and secondary to systemic diseases.
  • Option D. Myelofibrosis: In myelofibrosis, the bone marrow becomes replaced by fibrous tissue, but it is generally classified as a myeloproliferative disorder with a cellular (not hypoplastic) marrow before the development of fibrosis. Myelofibrosis is listed under pancytopenia with cellular bone marrow.

     

Educational Objective: 

 

Fanconi anemia is a constitutional form of aplastic anemia with hypoplastic bone marrow, while other causes of pancytopenia like PNH, hypersplenism, and myelofibrosis typically present with normal or increased marrow cellularity.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan region presents with multiple ulcers on the leg. Which of the following is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Sporothrix schenckii

 

Explanation:

 

The case describes a patient from the sub-Himalayan region with multiple ulcers on the leg. This clinical presentation strongly suggests sporotrichosis, which is caused by Sporothrix schenckii. Sporotrichosis is frequently encountered in gardeners, forest workers and manual laborers, with the sub-Himalayan hilly areas being an endemic region in India. The disease typically manifests as noduloulcerative lesions that develop following traumatic implantation, such as from a thorn prick, which is common in agricultural workers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trichophyton rubrum: Incorrect because T. rubrum is a dermatophyte that causes superficial mycoses like tinea (ringworm) infections. It typically presents with circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy lesions rather than ulcers. Dermatophytoses don't typically progress to form multiple ulcers as described in this case.

 

Option B. Cudotrichum species: This genus is not a known human pathogen causing subcutaneous or cutaneous infections with the presentation described.

 

Option D. Aspergillus: Incorrect because Aspergillus species predominantly cause respiratory infections (allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, or invasive aspergillosis) or superficial infections like otomycosis. They don't typically cause multiple cutaneous ulcers in immunocompetent individuals, especially not in the pattern described for this farmer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Sporotrichosis is a chronic subcutaneous mycosis caused by Sporothrix schenckii that frequently affects agricultural workers and presents as noduloulcerative lesions along lymphatics (lymphocutaneous form) following minor trauma, with the sub-Himalayan region being an endemic area for this infection in India.

choices.text: X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets
Vitamin D dependent rickets type I
Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

 

  • X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder characterized by low phosphate levels in the blood due to impaired phosphate reabsorption by the kidneys. This condition can lead to bone deformities, bony pain, and growth delays. Normal PTH levels are consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Other Options

 

Option A: Nutritional rickets:

  • Nutritional rickets is typically caused by a deficiency of Vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate. In this case, the boy has normal serum PTH, which suggests that his body is not compensating for a Vitamin D deficiency. Additionally, his phosphate levels are low despite Vitamin D supplementation, which is not characteristic of nutritional rickets.

 

Option C: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I:

  • This condition is caused by a genetic mutation that impairs the conversion of Vitamin D to its active form. It usually presents with low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which is not in line with the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Option D: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II:

  • Vitamin D dependent rickets type II is another genetic disorder that affects the body's response to Vitamin D. It can lead to low calcium levels and elevated PTH, which do not match the boy's normal PTH levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that results in low phosphate levels and can present with bony pain, developmental delay, and recurrent infections. It is distinct from other forms of rickets due to its genetic basis and the characteristic low phosphate levels in the absence of Vitamin D response.

 

Ref- https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/

choices.text: Segment la is due to residual urine
Segment II is due to Laplace law
Micturition fails to happen in segment II
The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Segment II is due to Laplace Law

 

Explanation:

 

The true statement regarding the given cystometrogram is that segment lb is due to Laplace law.

 

The law of Laplace correlates volume and wall tension, is applicable to urine storage.

 

According to Law of Laplace, the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R.

 

As the bladder gets filled, the radius increases along with the tension, hence there is a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full, which explains the flatness of the graph in segment II

 

The first urge to void is felt at a bladder volume of about 150 mL. A marked sense of fullness is felt at a bladder volume of 400ml.

 

Cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

 

 

  1. Initial Filling Phase (or Low-Pressure Phase): This phase represents the storage phase of bladder function.
  2. Rapid Filling Phase (or High-Pressure Phase): In this phase, the intravesical pressure increases more rapidly as the bladder volume reaches a certain threshold. The detrusor muscle, which contracts to initiate bladder emptying, starts to generate increased pressure as the bladder approaches its capacity. This phase represents the transition from storage to voiding phase.
  3. Voiding Phase (or Micturition Phase): In the voiding phase, the intravesical pressure rises to its highest level as the detrusor muscle contracts forcefully to empty the bladder. The pressure exceeds the urethral resistance, resulting in urine expulsion. This phase is associated with the sensation of needing to urinate and the act of micturition (urination).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Segment Ia is due to residual urine: Incorrect. Segment I, particularly the initial part of the curve, typically represents the early filling phase of the bladder, not necessarily residual urine.

 

Option C. Micturition fails to happen in segment II: Incorrect. Segment II represents the continuation of the filling phase; micturition (urination) does not occur here because it typically begins when the bladder reaches its threshold capacity and the detrusor muscle contracts, which would be represented later in the graph.

 

Option D. The dotted line represents that micturition has occurred: Incorrect. The dotted line likely indicates phase transitions within the bladder's filling and voiding cycle, not necessarily the occurrence of micturition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Segment II of a cystometrogram, characterized by Laplace's Law, illustrates how the bladder can accommodate increasing volumes of urine with minimal increase in pressure, showcasing the bladder's compliance during the urine storage phase. This is crucial for diagnosing and managing conditions related to bladder storage and voiding dysfunction.

questions.text: Preservative commonly used for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination is: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Formalin

 

  • Chemical for preservation for histopathology samples: Formalin. But it is not used as preservative for Toxicological analysis because extraction of poison becomes difficult.
  • Chemicals used for Preservation of Viscera for Toxicological analysis: Anyone of the following two preservatives may be used:

 

1) Saturated solution of common salt (NaCl, i.e. sodium chloride):

 

  1. Most commonly used preservative (easily available & cheap)
  2. It is indicated in all poisoning cases except Corrosives

 

2) Rectified spirit:

 

  1. Best preservative
  2. Indicated for most of the poisons except alcohol, acetic acid, Chloral hydrate, Chloroform, formaldehyde, formic acid, kerosene, phosphorus, paraldehyde, Phenol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ethyl Alcohol: Not commonly used for histopathological tissue preservation due to its dehydration properties, which can alter tissue morphology.

 

Option C. Saturated Salt Solution: Commonly used as a preservative for toxicological analysis. It is easy to obtain and cost-effective. However, it is not suitable for preserving tissue for histopathology because it does not adequately preserve tissue morphology and detail.

 

Option D. Normal Saline: Primarily used for medical procedures and as a temporary transport medium. It does not provide the long-term preservation needed for histopathological examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Formalin is the preservative of choice for soft tissue preservation for histopathological examination due to its ability to maintain tissue morphology and cellular details.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is incorrect? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B. Raised Alkaline Phosphatase

 

Explanation:

 

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia but normal alkaline phosphatase levels. This benign, rare disorder features defective expression of MRP2 (multidrug resistance-associated protein 2), an ATP-dependent canalicular membrane transporter responsible for biliary excretion of bilirubin conjugates. Despite the conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, liver tests other than bilirubin are typically normal in Dubin-Johnson syndrome, including alkaline phosphatase, which distinguishes it from other causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia like obstruction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conjugated Hyperbilirubinemia: Dubin-Johnson syndrome presents with predominantly conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with total bilirubin concentrations typically between 34-85 μmol/L (2-5 mg/dL).

 

Option C. Dark or Black liver on histology: A cardinal feature of Dubin-Johnson syndrome is the accumulation of dark, coarsely granular pigment in the lysosomes of centrilobular hepatocytes, resulting in a grossly black appearance of the liver.

 

Option D. Mutation of MRP2 Gene: Several different mutations in the MRP2 gene produce the Dubin-Johnson phenotype. MRP2 is undoubtedly important in the biliary excretion of conjugated bilirubin, and its defective expression is the molecular basis of this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dubin-Johnson syndrome is distinguished from other causes of conjugated hyperbilirubinemia by normal liver biochemical tests (including normal alkaline phosphatase), and characteristic black pigmentation of the liver resulting from MRP2 deficiency.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis for a 13-year-old boy with a history of chronic and recurrent itchy flexural lesions, considering his family history of asthma?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Atopic dermatitis

 

The image displays scratch marks and excoriations caused by pruritic lesions at a flexural site. The patient has a personal history of chronic and recurrent course, and there is also a family history of atopy, specifically asthma. These findings suggest a diagnosis of atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema (AE).

 

Atopic dermatitis (AD):

 

  • It is a chronic inflammatory condition that tends to persist or exhibit chronic relapses.
  • In infants, the first site of involvement is often the face.
  • Flexural distribution is observed in both the childhood and adult phases of the condition, while in the infantile phase, extensor distribution is more typical.

 

Atopic eczema can be divided into 3 phases:

 

  1. Infantile
  2. Childhood
  3. Adult

 

 

Atopic eczema infantile variant with face affected:

 

 

  • Atopic dermatitis typically presents with erythematous papules or papulovesicular lesions, often appearing in early childhood.
  • As the condition progresses, the lesions may evolve into excoriated and lichenified areas. Atopic dermatitis is commonly associated with secondary infections and skin dryness.
  • In the diagnosis of atopic dermatitis, the UK refinement of the Hanifin & Rajka criteria is employed.

 

UK refinement of Hanifin & Rajka’s diagnostic criteria of atopic dermatitis (Eczema).

 

  • An itchy skin condition (or parental report of scratching or rubbing in a child)
  • Plus, three or more of the following
    1. Onset below age 2 years (not used if child is under 4 years)
    2. History of skin crease involvement (including cheeks in children under 10 years)
    3. History of a generally dry skin
    4. Personal history of other atopic disease (or history of any atopic disease in a first degree relative in children under 4 years)
    5. Visible flexural dermatitis (or dermatitis of cheeks/ forehead and outer limbs in children under 4 years)

 

Clinical features of AD include:

 

  • Dennie-morgan fold under lower eyelid
  • Allergic shiners – periorbital pigmentation
  • Allergic salute – horizontal groove on dorsum of nasal bridge

 

Fig: Dennie-morgan fold

 

Complications of AD:

  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism to cause secondary infections in the lesions of atopic dermatitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Seborrheic dermatitis:

 

  • This is a chronic condition that primarily affects sebum-rich areas of the body such as the scalp, face, and central chest.
  • It's characterized by yellowish, greasy scales and underlying erythema as shown in the image below.

 

 

  • While it can be itchy, its distribution and features are different from the description given.
  • There is no direct association between seborrheic dermatitis and a family history of asthma.

 

Option C. Allergic contact dermatitis:

 

  • This results from direct skin contact with allergens. It's an immunological response to a substance the individual has become sensitized to.
  • The lesions would be more correlated with contact to specific allergens, and it's not typically chronic or recurrent unless there is repeated exposure to the same allergen.
  • The distribution would be more in line with areas that contacted the allergen, rather than the typical flexural pattern described.

 

Option D. Erysipelas:

 

  • Erysipelas is an acute bacterial skin infection, typically caused by Group A Streptococcus.
  • It presents as a well-demarcated, raised, erythematous, and tender skin lesion, often accompanied by systemic symptoms like fever.
  • This condition is acute, not chronic or recurrent as described in the scenario.
  • There's no association with a family history of asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Identify atopic dermatitis as a chronic, pruritic inflammatory skin disease commonly associated with flexural distribution of eczematous lesions and a family history of atopic conditions, such as asthma.

 

 

Reference:

Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 2 Chapter 41 page no 41.1, 41.2, 41.13-19

Rooks’ textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition volume 3 Chapter 149 page no 149.21

Online resources:

https://www.jaad.org/article/S0190-9622(13)01095-5/fulltext

questions.text: A 32-year-old male needs to be dressed in female lingerie and high heels to feel aroused and have intercourse with a female; he denies any sexual attraction towards males. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic fetishism

 

Transvestic fetishism involves the act of cross-dressing to achieve sexual arousal. In this case, the individual derives sexual excitement from wearing female clothing while engaging in sexual activity with females, which is characteristic of transvestic fetishism. He denies any attraction toward males, which further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender dysphoria involves a strong discomfort or distress with one’s assigned gender and a desire to be the opposite gender. There is no evidence in this scenario of dissatisfaction with his gender identity or discomfort with his sexual organs, ruling out gender dysphoria.

 

Option C. Homosexual orientation: Homosexual orientation refers to sexual attraction toward members of the same sex. The individual in this scenario specifically denies any sexual attraction to males, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

 

Option D. Testicular feminization: Testicular feminization, or Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome, is a genetic condition where an individual has a male karyotype (XY) but develops as a female due to insensitivity to androgens. This condition is unrelated to sexual arousal patterns or behaviors, and there is no evidence to support this diagnosis in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic fetishism is characterized by sexual arousal from cross-dressing in individuals who do not have discomfort with their gender identity.

questions.text: In the management of a thyroid storm, a critical and life-threatening condition due to an excess of thyroid hormone, a variety of medications are used to control the symptoms and the overactive thyroid. Which of the following drugs is not typically used in the treatment of thyroid storm? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Aspirin

 

Aspirin is avoided in thyroid storm because it can displace thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially increasing the levels of active thyroid hormone in the blood and exacerbating the condition.

 

Other Options

 

Thyroid storm is a severe hypermetabolic state caused by an excessive release of thyroid hormones (thyrotoxicosis). The standard treatment includes:

 

Option A. Propranolol: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker that is used to manage the sympathetic symptoms of thyrotoxicosis like tachycardia, tremors, and anxiety. It also inhibits the peripheral conversion of T4 to the more active T3.

 

Option B. Lugol’s Iodine: Lugol's Iodine is given to decrease the synthesis and release of thyroid hormones. The high iodine content temporarily inhibits the synthesis of thyroid hormones (the Wolff-Chaikoff effect) and blocks their release into the circulation.

 

Option C. Acetaminophen: Acetaminophen (paracetamol) is preferred for fever control in thyroid storm. It does not have the anti-inflammatory properties that might interfere with thyroid hormone levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Aspirin is not used in the treatment of thyroid storm because it can increase free thyroid hormone levels by displacing thyroid hormones from their binding proteins, potentially worsening the condition.

questions.text: Which disorder associated with the ATP 7A gene results in low serum copper levels? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Menkes disease

 

Explanation: 

 

Menkes disease is a disorder characterized by low serum copper levels due to mutations in the ATP7A gene. This gene encodes a copper-transporting ATPase that is responsible for copper absorption from the intestine and distribution to various tissues. When this gene is mutated, copper cannot be properly absorbed from the intestinal tract, leading to copper deficiency. This X-linked recessive disorder manifests with neurological deterioration, growth failure, and characteristic kinky hair (described as "steel wool" hair) due to abnormal copper-dependent cross-linking in hair proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dubin-Johnson's syndrome - This is a benign disorder characterized by conjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by mutations in the ABCC2 gene, which encodes a transport protein that moves bilirubin out of hepatocytes. It has no relation to copper metabolism.

 

Option B. Wilson disease - This is actually the opposite condition of Menkes disease. Wilson disease is caused by mutations in the ATP7B gene (not ATP7A) and results in excessive copper accumulation in tissues, particularly the liver and brain, rather than copper deficiency.

 

Option D. Gilbert's disease - This is another benign disorder affecting bilirubin metabolism, characterized by mild unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia due to reduced activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It has no connection to copper metabolism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Menkes disease is an X-linked disorder of copper metabolism caused by mutations in the ATP7A gene, resulting in impaired copper absorption and transport, which leads to copper deficiency manifesting as growth failure, neurological deterioration, and characteristic kinky hair.

questions.text: An epileptic patient presents with gum hypertrophy and bleeding. Which antiepileptic drug is the likely cause? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Phenytoin

 

Explanation:

 

Phenytoin is known to cause gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and bleeding as adverse effects. The adverse effects of phenytoin can be remembered using the mnemonic 

 

"HOT MALIKA":

 

H: Hirsutism and Hypertrophy of gums

O: Osteomalacia

T: Teratogenicity (fetal hydantoin syndrome)

M: Megaloblastic anemia (due to folate deficiency)

A: Arrhythmias (in overdose)

L: Lymph node enlargement (lymphadenopathy)

I: Inhibition of insulin secretion (can lead to hyperglycemia)

K: Vitamin K deficiency (can result in bleeding)

A: Ataxia, nystagmus, vertigo (cerebellar side effects in overdose)

 

The gum hypertrophy is a direct effect of phenytoin on gingival tissue, while the bleeding is due to vitamin K deficiency caused by phenytoin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Valproate: 

 

Valproate's adverse effects include 

 

V - Vomiting

A - Alopecia/Curling of hair

L - Liver disease (hepatotoxicity: in young children has high incidence)

P - Pancreatitis, ↑ risk of PCOD (gender Specific S/E)

R - Rash, allergy

O - Obesity

A - Ataxia (in overdose)

TE - Teratogenicity (most teratogenic Antiepileptic drug)

 

Therefore, if administered during pregnancy, a high dose of folic acid (4000μg/day) should be supplemented to prevent neural tube defects.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine: 

 

Carbamazepine's adverse effects can be remembered as "4 A's":

 

  • Auto-induction (increases metabolism of itself and other drugs)
  • Aplastic anemia (bone marrow suppression)
  • ADH release (which can cause SIADH and dilutional hyponatremia)
  • Ataxia/nystagmus/vertigo (in overdose)

 

It does not cause gum hypertrophy or vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding.

 

Option D. Ethosuximide: Ethosuximide primarily affects T-type calcium channels and is used mainly for absence seizures. Its adverse effects are relatively mild compared to other antiepileptics and do not include gum hypertrophy or bleeding. The main side effects are gastrointestinal disturbances and CNS effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phenytoin causes gum hypertrophy (gingival hyperplasia) and vitamin K deficiency leading to bleeding as characteristic adverse effects, which can be remembered using the mnemonic 

 

"HOT MALIKA."

 

Adverse Effects 

 

H - Hirsutism, Hypertrophy of gums 

O-Osteomalacia 

T- Teratogenicity [Fetal Hydantoin syndrome] 

M - Megaloblastic Anemia [↓ Folate] 

A- Arrhythmia [Only in overdose] 

L- Lymph node enlargement 

I - ↓Insulin (avoided in DM) 

K-↓ Vitamin K 

A - Ataxias, vertigo [cerebellar symptoms] only at high dose]

questions.text: The condition shown in the picture below is associated with which chromosomal abnormality? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 45XO

 

The image depicts a young female with features characteristic of Turner syndrome, which is associated with the chromosomal abnormality 45X0. Turner syndrome is characterized by a complete or partial absence of one of the X chromosomes. Key clinical features include short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and delayed puberty. These physical findings align with the typical presentation of Turner syndrome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 47XXY (Klinefelter syndrome): Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males and is characterized by the presence of an extra X chromosome (47XXY). This condition typically presents with tall stature, gynecomastia, and infertility, which do not match the features seen in the image.

 

Option C. 46X0 (XO mosaic): This option describes a mosaic form of Turner syndrome where some cells have a single X chromosome (45X0) while others have a typical female karyotype (46XX). While this is possible, the features described are more characteristic of classical Turner syndrome (45X0).

 

Option D. 48XY (Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome - AIS): AIS occurs in individuals with a male karyotype (46XY) but with insensitivity to androgens, resulting in incomplete or complete female external genitalia. However, AIS does not typically present with short stature, webbed neck, or widely spaced nipples, which are key features of Turner syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Turner syndrome (45X0) presents with short stature, webbed neck, widely spaced nipples, and delayed puberty. Recognizing these phenotypic patterns is crucial for diagnosing and managing patients with developmental and reproductive disorders.

questions.text: Structures passing between marked points A and B? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Stylopharyngeus

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts into the pharyngeal wall. It is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) and functions to elevate the pharynx during swallowing and speaking.

 

 

 

The gaps in the pharyngeal wall and structures passing thorugh them

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Palatopharyngeus: This muscle runs from the soft palate to the pharynx, but it does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors. Instead, it is involved in forming the palatopharyngeal arch.

 

Option C. Stylohyoid: This muscle originates from the styloid process and inserts onto the hyoid bone. It is involved in elevating the hyoid bone during swallowing but does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Option D. Mylohyoid: This muscle forms the floor of the mouth and is involved in elevating the floor of the mouth during swallowing. It does not pass between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The stylopharyngeus muscle passes between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors, and it is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX).

questions.text: Identify the marked area in the image shown below. (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pressure epiphysis 

 

  • A pressure epiphysis is the portion of the long bone that shapes the joint. 
  • Pressure epiphyses are the regions of the bone that are under pressure during movement or locomotion and aid in transmitting the weight of the human body. 
  • The head of the humerus, femoral and tibial condyles, ankle joint are the examples. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Atavistic epiphysis: A phylogenetically independent bone that has been fused with another bone. The coracoid process of the scapula, which has been fused in humans but is distinct in four-legged animals, is an example of atavistic fused bones. Another example of atavistic epiphysis is the os trigonum (posterior tubercle of the talus).

 

Option C. Traction epiphysis: The non-articular regions of the long bone, which are not involved in joint formation. These areas do not aid in weight transmission. The supporting ligaments and tendons bind to these areas of the bone due to their proximity to the pressure epiphysis site. Pressure epiphyses ossify first, followed by traction epiphyses. Tubercles of the humerus and trochanters of the femur are examples of traction epiphyses.

 

Option D. Aberrant epiphysis: These epiphyses are not necessarily present and are deviated from the standard. The epiphysis at the head of the first metacarpal bone, as well as the epiphysis at the base of other metacarpal bones, are examples.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the ankle joint. 
  • The joints are formed by the pressure epiphysis regions which are weight bearing areas. 
  • Thus, the ankle joint is an example of pressure epiphysis.

questions.text: A 80-year-old male patient presents with a PSA level of 7 ng/mL and a small tumor focus in prostate with a Gleason score of 6, what would be the most appropriate course of action for management?(NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Active surveillance

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of a diagnosis of low-risk prostatic carcinoma. The most likely management for this patient would be active surveillance only.

  • Active surveillance is a management approach used for prostate cancer with specific criteria.
  • Criteria for active surveillance include Gleason score 6, early-stage disease (T1), small volume disease on biopsy, age > 70 years and low PSA (<10 ng/mL).
  • Active surveillance protocols include regular digital rectal examination and PSA monitoring every 3 to 6 months, with TRUS-guided prostate biopsies every 1 to 3 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radical prostatectomy: This surgical procedure involves removing the entire prostate gland. It is often considered for prostate cancer treatment, especially for younger, healthier patients or those with more aggressive forms of the disease.

 

Option B. External beam radiation: This treatment involves using targeted radiation beams to kill cancer cells. It can be considered for prostate cancer, particularly when surgery is not an option. The choice between radiation therapy and active surveillance depends on various factors, including the patient's age, overall health, and the stage and aggressiveness of the cancer.

 

Option C. Brachytherapy: Brachytherapy is a form of radiation therapy where radioactive seeds or sources are placed directly into or near the tumor. It's a localized treatment and can be used for low to intermediate-risk prostate cancer. Again, the decision to use brachytherapy depends on several factors, including the patient's overall health and the characteristics of the cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Active surveillance is an appropriate management strategy for older patients with low-risk prostate cancer, characterized by a Gleason score of 6, early-stage disease, small tumor volume, and low PSA levels.
  • This approach minimizes unnecessary treatments and associated side effects, focusing on regular monitoring to detect any changes in the cancer's status.
